Text

The Rome Express , [the direttissimo]141-the direttissimo , or most direct , was approaching [Paris]1-paris one morning in March , when it became known to [the occupants of [the sleeping - car]143-the sleeping - car]142-the occupants of the sleeping - car that there was something amiss , very much amiss , in [the car]144-the car . [The train]145-the train was travelling the last stage , between [Laroche]2-laroche and [Paris]1-paris , a run of a hundred miles without a stop . [It]145-the train had halted at [Laroche]2-laroche for early breakfast , and [many , if not all the passengers]146-many , if not all the passengers , had turned out . Of those in [the sleeping - car]143-the sleeping - car , seven in number , six had been seen in [the restaurant]148-the restaurant , or about [the platform]149-the platform ; [the seventh]150-the seventh , [a lady]151-a lady , had not stirred . [All]152-all had reëntered [their]152-all berths to sleep or doze when [the train]145-the train went on , but several were on the move as [it]145-the train neared [Paris]1-paris , taking [their]152-all turn at [the lavatory]154-the lavatory , calling for water , towels , making the usual stir of preparation as the end of a journey was at hand . There were many calls for [the porter]155-the porter , yet [no porter]156-no porter appeared . At last [the attendant]157-the attendant was found — lazy villain!--asleep , snoring loudly , stertorously , in [[his]157-the attendant little bunk at the end of [the car]144-the car]158-his little bunk at the end of the car . [He]157-the attendant was roused with difficulty , and set about [his]157-the attendant work in a dull , unwilling , lethargic way , which promised badly for [his]157-the attendant tips from those [he]157-the attendant was supposed to serve . By degrees [all the passengers]160-all the passengers got dressed , all but two,—the lady in 9 and 10 , who had made no sign as yet ; and [the man who occupied alone [a double berth next [her]163-her]162-a double berth next her , numbered 7 and 8 . As it was [the porter]155-the porter 's duty to call [every one]165-every one , and as [he]155-the porter was anxious , like the rest of [[his]155-the porter class]166-his class , to get rid of [[his]155-the porter travellers]167-his travellers]161-the man who occupied alone a double berth next her , numbered 7 and 8 . as it was the porter 's duty to call every one , and as he was anxious , like the rest of his class , to get rid of his travellers as soon as possible after arrival , [he]155-the porter rapped at each of the two closed doors behind which [people]168-people presumably still slept . [The lady]169-the lady cried " All right , "[169-the lady] but there was no answer from No . 7 and 8 . Again and again [the porter]155-the porter knocked and called loudly . Still meeting with no response , [he]155-the porter opened the door of [the compartment]171-the compartment and went in . It was now broad daylight . No blind was down ; indeed , the one narrow window was open , wide ; and the whole of the interior of [the compartment]171-the compartment was plainly visible , all and everything in [it]171-the compartment . [The occupant]173-the occupant lay on [his]173-the occupant bed motionless . Sound asleep ? No , not merely asleep — the twisted unnatural lie of the limbs , the contorted legs , the one arm drooping listlessly but stiffly over the side of [the berth]174-the berth , told of a deeper , more eternal sleep . [The man]175-the man was dead . Dead — and not from natural causes . One glance at the blood - stained bedclothes , one look at the gaping wound in the breast , at the battered , mangled face , told the terrible story . It was murder ! murder most foul ! [The victim]176-the victim had been stabbed to the heart . With a wild , affrighted , cry [the porter]155-the porter rushed out of [the compartment]171-the compartment , and to the eager questioning of all who crowded round [him]155-the porter , [he]155-the porter could only mutter in confused and trembling accents : " There ! there ! in there ! "[155-the porter] Thus the fact of the murder became known to [every one]165-every one by personal inspection , for every one ( even [the lady]169-the lady had appeared for just a moment ) had looked in where the body lay . [The compartment]171-the compartment was filled for some ten minutes or more by an excited , gesticulating , polyglot mob of half a dozen , all talking at once in French , English , and Italian . The first attempt to restore order was made by [a tall man , middle - aged , but erect in [his]182-a tall man , middle - aged , but erect in his bearing , with bright eyes and alert manner , who took the porter bearing , with bright eyes and alert manner , who took [the porter]155-the porter]182-a tall man , middle - aged , but erect in his bearing , with bright eyes and alert manner , who took the porter aside , and said sharply in good French , but with a strong English accent : " Here ! it 's [your]155-the porter business to do something . [No one]1227-no one has any right to be in [that compartment]1228-that compartment now . There may be reasons — traces — things to remove ; never mind what . But get them all out . Be sharp about it ; and lock the door . Remember [you]155-the porter will be held responsible to justice . "[155-the porter] [The porter]155-the porter shuddered , so did [many of [the passengers who had overheard [the Englishman]55-the englishman]186-the passengers who had overheard the englishman 's last words . Justice]185-many of the passengers who had overheard the englishman 's last words . justice ! It is not to be trifled with anywhere , least of all in [France]3-france , where the uncomfortable superstition prevails that [every one who can be reasonably suspected of a crime]187-every one who can be reasonably suspected of a crime is held to be guilty of that crime until [his]187-every one who can be reasonably suspected of a crime innocence is clearly proved . [All those six passengers]188-all those six passengers and [the porter]155-the porter were now brought within the category of [the accused]190-the accused . [They]188-all those six passengers were all open to suspicion ; [they]188-all those six passengers , and [they]188-all those six passengers alone , for [the murdered man]191-the murdered man had been seen alive at [Laroche]2-laroche , and the fell deed must have been done since then , while [the train]145-the train was in transit , that is to say , going at express speed , when [no one]1227-no one could leave [it]145-the train except at peril of [his]191-the murdered man life . " Deuced awkward for [us]197-we ! "[194-the tall english general] said [the tall English general]194-the tall english general , [Sir Charles Collingham]56-sir charles by name , to [[his]194-the tall english general brother]195-his brother [the parson]196-the parson , when [he]194-the tall english general had reëntered [[their]197-we compartment]198-their compartment and shut the door . " [I]57-silas collingham ca n't see it . In what way ? "[57-silas collingham] asked the Reverend [Silas Collingham]57-silas collingham , [a typical English cleric]199-a typical english cleric , with a rubicund face and square - cut white whiskers , dressed in a suit of black serge , and wearing the professional white tie . " Why , [we]197-we shall be detained , of course ; arrested , probably — certainly detained . Examined , cross - examined , bully - ragged — [I]57-silas collingham know something of [the French police]1229-the french police and [their]1229-the french police ways . "[57-silas collingham] " If [they]1229-the french police stop [us]197-we , [I]195-his brother shall write to [the Times]1230-the times "[195-his brother] cried [[his]57-silas collingham brother]195-his brother , by profession [a man of peace , but with a choleric eye that told of an angry temperament]201-a man of peace , but with a choleric eye that told of an angry temperament . " By all means , [[my]195-his brother dear]1231-my dear [Silas]57-silas collingham , when [you]57-silas collingham get the chance . That wo n't be just yet , for [I]195-his brother tell [you]57-silas collingham [we]197-we 're in a tight place , and may expect a good deal of worry . "[195-his brother] With that [he]195-his brother took out [his]195-his brother cigarette - case , and [his]195-his brother match - box , lighted [his]195-his brother cigarette , and calmly watched the smoke rising with all the coolness of [an old campaigner accustomed to encounter and face the ups and downs of life]202-an old campaigner accustomed to encounter and face the ups and downs of life . " [I]195-his brother only hope to goodness [they]1232-they 'll run straight on to [Paris]1-paris , "[195-his brother] [he]195-his brother added in a fervent tone , not unmixed with apprehension . [It]1233-it 's right [the conductor]1234-the conductor , or chief of [the train]145-the train , or whatever [you]57-silas collingham call [him]1234-the conductor , should know what has happened . "[195-his brother] " Why , [man]1236-man , ca n't [you]1236-man see ? While [the train]145-the train is travelling express , [every one]165-every one must stay on board [it]145-the train ; if it slows , it is possible to leave [it]145-the train . "[195-his brother] " Who would want to leave [it]145-the train ? "[195-his brother] " Oh , [I]203-the general do n't know , "[203-the general] said [the General]203-the general , rather testily . " Any way , the thing 's done now . "[203-the general] [The train]145-the train had pulled up in obedience to the signal of alarm given by [some one in [the sleeping - car]143-the sleeping - car]205-some one in the sleeping - car , but by whom it was impossible to say . Not by [the porter]155-the porter , for [he]155-the porter seemed greatly surprised as [the conductor]1234-the conductor came up to [him]155-the porter . " How did [you]1234-the conductor know ? "[1234-the conductor] [he]1234-the conductor asked . " Know ! Know what ? [You]1234-the conductor stopped [me]1234-the conductor . "[1234-the conductor] " [I]155-the porter did n't . "[155-the porter] " [Who rang the bell]1239-who rang the bell , then ? "[155-the porter] " [I]1234-the conductor did not . But [I]1234-the conductor 'm glad [you]1234-the conductor 've come . There has been a crime — murder . "[1234-the conductor] " Good Heavens ! "[1234-the conductor] cried [the conductor]1234-the conductor , jumping up on to [the car]144-the car , and entering into the situation at once . [His]1234-the conductor business was only to verify the fact , and take all necessary precautions . [He]1234-the conductor was [a burly , brusque , peremptory person]211-a burly , brusque , peremptory person , [the despotic , self - important French official , who knew what to do — as [he]1234-the conductor thought — and did it without hesitation or apology]212-the despotic , self - important french official , who knew what to do — as he thought — and did it without hesitation or apology . " [No one]1227-no one must leave [the car]144-the car , "[1234-the conductor] [he]1234-the conductor said in a tone not to be misunderstood . " Neither now , nor on arrival at [the station]1242-the station . "[1234-the conductor] There was a shout of protest and dismay , which [he]1234-the conductor quickly cut short . " [You]1234-the conductor will have to arrange it with [the authorities in [Paris]1-paris]1243-the authorities in paris ; [they]1243-the authorities in paris can alone decide . [My]1234-the conductor duty is plain : to detain [you]1234-the conductor , place [you]1234-the conductor under surveillance till then . Afterwards , [we]1244-we will see . Enough , [gentlemen]1245-gentlemen and [madame]1246-madame "[1234-the conductor] — [He]1234-the conductor bowed with the instinctive gallantry of [[his]1234-the conductor nation]213-his nation to [the female figure which now appeared at the door of [[her]214-the female figure which now appeared at the door of her compartment compartment]215-her compartment]214-the female figure which now appeared at the door of her compartment . [She]214-the female figure which now appeared at the door of her compartment stood for a moment listening , seemingly greatly agitated , and then , without a word , disappeared , retreating hastily into [[her]214-the female figure which now appeared at the door of her compartment own private room]216-her own private room , where [she]214-the female figure which now appeared at the door of her compartment shut [herself]214-the female figure which now appeared at the door of her compartment in . Almost immediately , at a signal from [the conductor]1234-the conductor , [the train]145-the train resumed its journey . The distance remaining to be traversed was short ; half an hour more , and [the [Lyons]4-lyons station]219-the lyons station , at [Paris]1-paris , was reached , where [the bulk of [the passengers]221-the passengers]220-the bulk of the passengers — all , indeed , but [the occupants of the sleeper]222-the occupants of the sleeper — descended and passed through the barriers . [The latter]223-the latter were again desired to keep [their]223-the latter places , while [a posse of [officials]225-officials]224-a posse of officials came and mounted guard . Presently [they]221-the passengers were told to leave [the car]144-the car one by one , but to take nothing with [them]221-the passengers . All [their]221-the passengers hand - bags , rugs , and belongings were to remain in [the berths]227-the berths , just as [they]221-the passengers lay . One by one [they]221-the passengers were marched under escort to [a large and bare waiting - room]228-a large and bare waiting - room , which had , no doubt , been prepared for [their]221-the passengers reception . Here [they]221-the passengers took [their]221-the passengers seats on chairs placed at wide intervals apart , and were peremptorily forbidden to hold any communication with [each other]229-each other , by word or gesture . This order was enforced by [a fierce - looking guard in blue and red uniform , who stood facing [them]221-the passengers]230-a fierce - looking guard in blue and red uniform , who stood facing them with [his]230-a fierce - looking guard in blue and red uniform , who stood facing them arms folded , gnawing [his]230-a fierce - looking guard in blue and red uniform , who stood facing them moustache and frowning severely . Last of all , [the porter]155-the porter was brought in and treated like [the passengers]221-the passengers , but more distinctly as [a prisoner]233-a prisoner . [He]155-the porter had [a guard]234-a guard all to [himself]155-the porter ; and it seemed as though [he]155-the porter was the object of peculiar suspicion . It had no great effect upon [him]155-the porter , for , while [the rest of the party]235-the rest of the party were very plainly sad , and a prey to lively apprehension , [the porter]155-the porter sat dull and unmoved , with the stolid , sluggish , unconcerned aspect of [a man]237-a man just roused from sound sleep and relapsing into slumber , who takes little notice of what is passing around . Meanwhile , [the sleeping - car]143-the sleeping - car , with [its]143-the sleeping - car contents , especially [the corpse of [the victim]176-the victim]239-the corpse of the victim , was shunted into a siding , and [sentries]241-sentries were placed on it at both ends . Seals had been affixed upon the entrance doors , so that the interior might be kept inviolate until [it]242-it could be visited and examined by [the Chef de la Surêté , or Chief of [the Detective Service]244-the detective service]243-the chef de la surêté , or chief of the detective service . [Every one and everything]245-every one and everything awaited the arrival of [this all - important functionary]246-this all - important functionary . [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon , [the Chief]247-the chief , was [an early man]248-an early man , and [he]247-the chief paid a first visit to [[his]247-the chief office]249-his office about 7 A.M. [He]247-the chief lived just round the corner in [the Rue des Arcs]250-the rue des arcs , and had not far to go to [the Prefecture]5-the prefecture . But even now , soon after daylight , [he]247-the chief was correctly dressed , as became [a responsible ministerial officer]251-a responsible ministerial officer . [He]247-the chief wore a tight frock coat and an immaculate white tie ; under [his]247-the chief arm [he]247-the chief carried the regulation portfolio , or [lawyer]252-lawyer 's bag , stuffed full of reports , dispositions , and documents dealing with cases in hand . [He]247-the chief was altogether [a very precise and natty little personage]253-a very precise and natty little personage , quiet and unpretending in demeanour , with a mild , thoughtful face in which two small ferrety eyes blinked and twinkled behind gold - rimmed glasses . But when things went wrong , when [he]247-the chief had to deal with [fools]254-fools , or when scent was keen , or the enemy near , [he]247-the chief would become as fierce and eager as [any terrier]255-any terrier . [He]247-the chief had just taken [his]247-the chief place at [his]247-the chief table and begun to arrange [his]247-the chief papers , which , being [a man of method]256-a man of method , [he]247-the chief kept carefully sorted by lots each in an old copy of the Figaro , when [he]247-the chief was called to the telephone . " [The passengers]221-the passengers have been detained ? "[58-m. floçon] asked [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon at once . "[175-the man] " Hah ! "[247-the chief] [The Chief]247-the chief thought [he]247-the chief understood . " Did [you]155-the porter feel this drowsiness before leaving [Laroche]2-laroche ? "[169-the lady] " Oh , [monsieur]1266-monsieur , [I]169-the lady was so anxious to continue [my]169-the lady journey . [Friends]1345-friends are awaiting [me]169-the lady in [London]12-london . [I]169-the lady do hope — [I]169-the lady most earnestly beg and entreat [you]1266-monsieur to spare [me]169-the lady . [I]169-the lady am not very strong ; [my]169-the lady health is indifferent . Do , [sir]1255-sir , be so good as to release [me]169-the lady from — "[169-the lady] As [she]169-the lady spoke , [she]169-the lady raised [her]169-the lady veil , and showed what [no woman]334-no woman wishes to hide , least of all when seeking the good - will of [one of the opposite sex]335-one of the opposite sex . [She]169-the lady had a handsome face — strikingly so . Not even the long journey , the fatigue , the worries and anxieties which had supervened , could rob [her]169-the lady of [her]169-the lady marvellous beauty . [She]169-the lady was [a brilliant brunette]336-a brilliant brunette , dark - skinned ; but [her]169-the lady complexion was of a clear , pale olive , and as soft , as lustrous as pure ivory . [Her]169-the lady great eyes , of a deep velvety brown , were saddened by near tears . [She]169-the lady had rich red lips , the only colour in [her]169-the lady face , and these , habitually slightly apart , showed pearly - white glistening teeth . It was difficult to look at [this charming woman]337-this charming woman without being affected by [her]169-the lady beauty . [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon was [a Frenchman]292-a frenchman , gallant and impressionable ; yet [he]58-m. floçon steeled [his]58-m. floçon heart . [A detective]339-a detective must beware of sentiment , and [he]58-m. floçon seemed to see something insidious in this appeal , which [he]58-m. floçon resented . " [Madame]66-madame la comtesse , it is useless , "[58-m. floçon] [he]58-m. floçon answered gruffly . " [I]58-m. floçon do not make the law ; [I]58-m. floçon have only to support it . [Every good citizen]1347-every good citizen is bound to that . "[58-m. floçon] " [I]340-the countess trust [I]340-the countess am [a good citizen]1348-a good citizen , "[340-the countess] said [the Countess]340-the countess , with a wan smile , but very wearily . " Still , [I]340-the countess should wish to be let off now . [I]340-the countess have suffered greatly , terribly , by this horrible catastrophe . [My]340-the countess nerves are quite shattered . It is too cruel . However , [I]340-the countess can say no more , except to ask that [you]1349-you will let [[my]340-the countess maid]1350-my maid come to [me]340-the countess . "[340-the countess] " No . Have [I]341-i not said so ? [The porter,"—here]1356-the porter,"—here[341-i] [she]341-i pointed to [the man]175-the man , who stood staring at [her]341-i from the other side of the table,—"he made difficulties about [her]1350-my maid being in [the car]144-the car , saying that [she]1350-my maid came too often , stayed too long , that [I]341-i must pay for [her]1350-my maid berth , and so on . [I]341-i did not see why [I]341-i should do that ; so [she]1350-my maid stayed away . "[341-i] " Except from time to time ? "[341-i] " Precisely . "[341-i] " And the last time was at [Amberieux]8-amberieux ? "[341-i] " As [I]341-i have told [you]341-i , and [he]175-the man will tell [you]341-i the same . "[341-i] " Thank [you]341-i , [madame]1246-madame , that will do . "[247-the chief] [The Chief]247-the chief rose from [his]247-the chief chair , plainly intimating that the interview was at an end . [He]247-the chief had other work to do , and was eager to get at it . So [he]247-the chief left [Block]60-block to show [the Countess]340-the countess back to [the waiting - room]269-the waiting - room , and , motioning to [the porter]155-the porter that [he]247-the chief might also go , [the Chief]247-the chief hastened to [the sleeping - car]143-the sleeping - car , the examination of which , too long delayed , claimed [his]247-the chief urgent attention . It is the first duty of [a good detective]349-a good detective to visit the actual theatre of a crime and overhaul it inch by inch,—seeking , searching , investigating , looking for any , even the most insignificant , traces of [the murderer]350-the murderer 's hands . [The sleeping - car]143-the sleeping - car , as [I]0-i have said , had been side - tracked , [its]143-the sleeping - car doors were sealed , and [it]143-the sleeping - car was under strict watch and ward . But everything , of course , gave way before [the detective]317-the detective , and , breaking through the seals , [he]317-the detective walked in , making straight for [the little room or compartment where the body of [the victim]176-the victim still lay untended and absolutely untouched]353-the little room or compartment where the body of the victim still lay untended and absolutely untouched . It was a ghastly sight , although not new in [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon 's experience . There lay the corpse in [the narrow berth]355-the narrow berth , just as [it]356-it had been stricken . [It]356-it was partially undressed , wearing only shirt and drawers . The former lay open at the chest , and showed the gaping wound that had , no doubt , caused death , probably instantaneous death . But other blows had been struck ; there must have been a struggle , fierce and embittered , as for dear life . The savage truculence of [the murderer]350-the murderer had triumphed , but not until [he]350-the murderer had battered in the face , destroying features and rendering recognition almost impossible . A knife had given the mortal wound ; that was at once apparent from the shape of the wound . [It]358-it was the knife , too , which had gashed and stabbed the face , almost wantonly ; for some of these wounds had not bled , and the plain inference was that they had been inflicted after life had sped . [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon examined the body closely , but without disturbing [it]356-it . [The police medical officer]359-the police medical officer would wish to see [it]356-it as it was found . The exact position , as well as the nature of the wounds , might afford evidence as to the manner of death . But [the Chief]247-the chief looked long , and with absorbed , concentrated interest , at [the murdered man]191-the murdered man , noting all [he]247-the chief actually saw , and conjecturing a good deal more . The features of the mutilated face were all but unrecognizable , but the hair , which was abundant , was long , black , and inclined to curl ; the black moustache was thick and drooping . The shirt was of fine linen , the drawers silk . On one finger were two good rings , the hands were clean , the nails well kept , and there was every evidence that [the man]175-the man did not live by manual labour . [He]175-the man was of the easy , cultured class , as distinct from [the workman]363-the workman or [operative]364-operative . This conclusion was borne out by [his]175-the man light baggage , which still lay about the berth,—hat - box , rugs , umbrella , brown morocco hand - bag . All were the property of some one well to do , or at least possessed of decent belongings . One or two pieces bore a monogram , " F.Q. , "[365-its owner] the same as on the shirt and under - linen ; but on the bag was a luggage label , with the name , " [Francis Quadling]74-francis quadling , passenger to [Paris]1-paris , "[58-m. floçon] in full . [Its owner]365-its owner had apparently no reason to conceal [his]175-the man name . More strangely , [those who had done [him]175-the man to death]366-those who had done him to death had been at no pains to remove all traces of [his]175-the man identity . [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon opened the hand - bag , seeking for further evidence ; but found nothing of importance,—only loose collars , cuffs , a sponge and slippers , two Italian newspapers of an earlier date . No money , valuables , or papers . All these had been removed probably , and presumably , by [the perpetrator of the crime]367-the perpetrator of the crime . Having settled the first preliminary but essential points , [he]58-m. floçon next surveyed [the whole compartment]368-the whole compartment critically . Now , for the first time , [he]58-m. floçon was struck with the fact that the window was open to its full height . Since when was this ? It was a question to be put presently to [the porter]155-the porter and [any others who had entered [the car]144-the car]370-any others who had entered the car , but the discovery drew [him]58-m. floçon to examine the window more closely , and with good results . At the ledge , caught on a projecting point on the far side , partly in , partly out of [the car]144-the car , was a morsel of white lace , a scrap of feminine apparel ; although what part , or how it had come there , was not at once obvious to [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon . A long and minute inspection of this bit of lace , which [he]58-m. floçon was careful not to detach as yet from the place in which [he]58-m. floçon found it , showed that it was ragged , and frayed , and fast caught where it hung . It could not have been blown there by any chance air ; it must have been torn from the article to which it belonged , whatever that might be,—head - dress , nightcap , night - dress , or handkerchief . The lace was of a kind to serve any of these purposes . Inspecting further , [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon made a second discovery . On the small table under the window was a short length of black jet beading , part of the trimming or ornamentation of [a lady]151-a lady 's dress . These two objects of feminine origin — one partly outside [the car]144-the car , the other near it , but quite inside — gave rise to many conjectures . It led , however , to the inevitable conclusion that [a woman]375-a woman had been at some time or other in [the berth]174-the berth . [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon could not but connect these two finds with the fact of the open window . The latter might , of course , have been the work of [the murdered man]191-the murdered man [himself]191-the murdered man at an earlier hour . Yet it is unusual , as [the detective]317-the detective imagined , for [a passenger]1302-a passenger , and especially [an Italian]320-an italian , to lie under an open window in [a sleeping - berth]381-a sleeping - berth when travelling by [express train]382-express train before daylight in [March]13-march . Who opened that window , then , and why ? Perhaps some further facts might be found on the outside of [the car]144-the car . With this idea , [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon left it , and passed on to the line or permanent way . Here [he]58-m. floçon found [himself]58-m. floçon a good deal below the level of [the car]144-the car . [These sleepers]385-these sleepers have no foot - boards like [ordinary carriages]386-ordinary carriages ; access to [them]385-these sleepers is gained from a platform by the steps at each end . [The Chief]247-the chief was short of stature , and [he]247-the chief could only approach the window outside by calling [one of [the guards]389-the guards]388-one of the guards and ordering [him]247-the chief to make the small ladder ( faire la petite echelle ) . This meant stooping and giving a back , on which little M. Floçon climbed nimbly , and so was raised to the necessary height . A close scrutiny revealed nothing unusual . The exterior of [the car]144-the car was encrusted with the mud and dust gathered in the journey , none of which appeared to have been disturbed . [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon reëntered [the carriage]391-the carriage neither disappointed nor pleased ; [his]58-m. floçon mind was in an open state , ready to receive any impressions , and as yet only one that was at all clear and distinct was borne in on [him]58-m. floçon . This was the presence of the lace and the jet beads in the theatre of the crime . The inference was fair and simple . [He]58-m. floçon came logically and surely to this : 1 . That [some woman]392-some woman had entered [the compartment]171-the compartment . 2 . That whether or not [she]392-some woman had come in before the crime , [she]392-some woman was there after the window had been opened , which was not done by [the murdered man]191-the murdered man . 3 . That [she]392-some woman had leaned out , or partly passed out , of the window at some time or other , as the scrap of lace testified . 4 . Why had [she]392-some woman leaned out ? To seek some means of exit or escape , of course . But escape from whom ? from what ? [The murderer]350-the murderer ? Then [she]392-some woman must know [him]350-the murderer , and unless [an accomplice]396-an accomplice ( if so , why run from [him]350-the murderer ? ) , [she]392-some woman would give up [her]392-some woman knowledge on compulsion , if not voluntarily , as seemed doubtful , seeing [she]392-some woman ( [his]350-the murderer suspicions were consolidating ) had not done so already . But there might be another even stronger reason to attempt escape at such imminent risk as leaving [an express train]397-an express train at full speed . To escape from [her]392-some woman own act and the consequences it must entail — escape from horror first , from detection next , and then from arrest and punishment . All this would imperiously impel even [a weak woman]398-a weak woman to face the worst peril , to look out , lean out , even try the terrible but impossible feat of climbing out of [the car]144-the car . So M. Floçon , by fair process of reasoning , reached a point which incriminated [one woman]400-one woman , [the only woman]401-the only woman possible , and that was [the titled , high - bred lady who called [herself]402-the titled , high - bred lady who called herself the contessa di castagneto [the Contessa di Castagneto]327-the contessa di castagneto]402-the titled , high - bred lady who called herself the contessa di castagneto . This conclusion gave a definite direction to further search . Consulting the rough plan which [he]350-the murderer had constructed to take the place of the missing train card , [he]350-the murderer entered [the compartment which [the Countess]340-the countess had occupied , and which was actually next door]404-the compartment which the countess had occupied , and which was actually next door . [It]404-the compartment which the countess had occupied , and which was actually next door was in the tumbled , untidy condition of [a sleeping - place but just vacated]406-a sleeping - place but just vacated . The sex and quality of [[its]404-the compartment which the countess had occupied , and which was actually next door recent occupant]407-its recent occupant were plainly apparent in the goods and chattels lying about , the property and possessions of [a delicate , well - bred woman of]408-a delicate , well - bred woman of [the world]409-the world , things still left as [she]408-a delicate , well - bred woman of had used them last — rugs still unrolled , a pair of easy - slippers on the floor , the sponge in its waterproof bag on the bed , brushes , bottles , button - hook , hand - glass , many things belonging to the dressing - bag , not yet returned to that receptacle . [The maid]1308-the maid was no doubt to have attended to all these , but as [she]1308-the maid had not come , they remained unpacked and strewn about in some disorder . [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon pounced down upon the contents of [the berth]174-the berth , and commenced an immediate search for a lace scarf , or any wrap or cover with lace . [He]350-the murderer found nothing , and was hardly disappointed . It told more against [the Countess]340-the countess , who , if innocent , would have no reason to conceal or make away with a possibly incriminating possession , the need for which [she]340-the countess could not of course understand . Next , [he]350-the murderer handled the dressing - bag , and with deft fingers replaced everything . Everything was forthcoming but one glass bottle , a small one , the absence of which [he]350-the murderer noted , but thought of little consequence , till , by and by , [he]350-the murderer came upon it under peculiar circumstances . Before leaving [the car]144-the car , and after walking through [the other compartments]414-the other compartments , [M. [He]350-the murderer had not forgotten [the attendant]157-the attendant 's condition when first examined , and [he]350-the murderer had even then been nearly satisfied that [the man]175-the man had been hocussed , narcotized , drugged . Any doubts were entirely removed by [his]350-the murderer picking up near [the porter]155-the porter 's seat a small silver - topped bottle and a handkerchief , both marked with coronet and monogram , the last of which , although the letters were much interlaced and involved , were decipherable as S.L.L.C. It was that of [the Countess]340-the countess , and corresponded with the marks on [her]340-the countess other belongings . [He]350-the murderer put it to [his]350-the murderer nostril , and recognized at once by its smell that it had contained tincture of laudanum , or some preparation of that drug . [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon was [an experienced detective]421-an experienced detective , and [he]350-the murderer knew so well that [he]350-the murderer ought to be on [his]350-the murderer guard against the most plausible suggestions , that [he]350-the murderer did not like to make too much of these discoveries . [[The lady]169-the lady 's maid]1310-the lady 's maid was not to be found . " Impossible ! "[247-the chief] cried [the Chief]247-the chief , and then at once suspicion followed surprise . "[247-the chief] This question presented itself as one of infinite importance , to be pondered over seriously before [he]429-he went further into the inquiry . " [I]429-he will try [her]1308-the maid further , "[429-he] said [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon to [himself]429-he . But then , supposing that [the maid]1308-the maid had taken [herself]1308-the maid off of [her]1308-the maid own accord ? Why was it ? Why had [she]1308-the maid done so ? "[203-the general] " Really , [Charles]56-sir charles , [I]492-the clergyman fear [you]56-sir charles are going too far , "[492-the clergyman] said [[his]203-the general brother]195-his brother [the clergyman]492-the clergyman , who , however , had been manifestly enjoying the whole scene . " Indeed , yes . " [Monsieur]1408-monsieur will not , [I]203-the general trust , oblige [us]1409-us to put in force the full power of the law . [A prisoner]233-a prisoner , practically friendless,—for [the General]203-the general was not within reach,—to resist was out of the question . " At whose instance was [the train]145-the train pulled up ? "[317-the detective] asked [the detective]317-the detective , and [the Judge]485-the judge nodded [his]485-the judge head approvingly . "[485-the judge] [he]485-the judge went on to ask [the General]203-the general . " That is surely [your]203-the general business . But if [you]203-the general wish , [I]485-the judge will tell [you]203-the general how it strikes [me]485-the judge . "[485-the judge] [The Judge]485-the judge bowed assent . " The bare fact that [the train]145-the train was halted would mean little . That would be the natural act of [a timid or excitable person]1683-a timid or excitable person involved indirectly in such a catastrophe . But to disavow the act starts suspicion . The fair inference is that there was some reason , an unavowable reason , for halting [the train]145-the train . "[485-the judge] " And that reason would be — "[485-the judge] " [You]203-the general must see it without [my]485-the judge assistance , surely ! Why , what else but to afford [some one]1386-some one an opportunity to leave [the car]144-the car . "[485-the judge] " But how could that be ? [You]203-the general would have seen [that person]1687-that person , some of [you]203-the general , especially at such a critical time . [The aisle]1688-the aisle would be full of [people]168-people , both exits were thus practically overlooked . "[485-the judge] " [My]485-the judge idea is — it is only an idea , understand — that [the person]1690-the person had already left [the car]144-the car — that is to say , the interior of [the car]144-the car . [The three officials]516-the three officials went straight to where the still open window showed the particular spot to be examined . The exterior of [the car]144-the car was a little smirched and stained with the dust of the journey , lying thick in parts , and in others there were a few great splotches of mud plastered on . [The detective]317-the detective paused for a moment to get a general view , looking , in the light of [the General]203-the general 's suggestion , for either hand or foot marks , anything like a trace of the passage of a feminine skirt , across the dusty surface . But nothing was to be seen , nothing definite or conclusive at least . Only here and there a few lines and scratches that might be encouraging , but proved little . Then [the Commissary]486-the commissary , drawing nearer , called attention to some suspicious spots sprinkled about the window , but above it towards the roof . " What is it ? " [I]317-the detective could not swear to it , but [I]317-the detective believe it is blood . "[317-the detective] " Blood ! Good Heavens ! " [I]155-the porter know nothing , "[155-the porter] [the porter]155-the porter protested , piteously . " That is false . [We]1817-we are fully informed and [no fools]1827-no fools . [We]1817-we are certain that no such catastrophe could have occurred without [your]155-the porter knowledge or connivance . "[62-groote] " Indeed , [gentlemen]1245-gentlemen , indeed — "[485-the judge] " [You]155-the porter were drinking with [this maid]1318-this maid at the buffet at [Laroche]2-laroche . [You]155-the porter had more drink with [her]1318-this maid , or from [her]1318-this maid hands , afterwards in [the car]144-the car . "[485-the judge] " No , [gentlemen]1245-gentlemen , that is not so . [I]485-the judge could not — [she]1318-this maid was not in [the car]144-the car . "[485-the judge] " [We]1817-we know better . [You]155-the porter can not deceive [us]1817-we . [You]155-the porter were [[her]1318-this maid accomplice]1833-her accomplice , and [the accomplice of [[her]1318-this maid mistress]1304-her mistress]1834-the accomplice of her mistress , also , [I]485-the judge have no doubt . "[485-the judge] " [I]485-the judge declare solemnly that [I]485-the judge am quite innocent of all this . [I]485-the judge hardly remember what happened at [Laroche]2-laroche or after . [I]485-the judge do not deny the drink at the buffet . It was very nasty , [I]485-the judge thought , and could not tell why , nor why [I]485-the judge could not hold [my]485-the judge head up when [I]485-the judge got back to [the car]144-the car . "[485-the judge] " [You]485-the judge went off to sleep at once ? Is that what [you]485-the judge pretend ? "[485-the judge] " It must have been so . Yes . Then [I]485-the judge know nothing more , not till [I]485-the judge was aroused . "[485-the judge] And beyond this , a tale to which [he]763-he stuck with undeviating persistence , [they]764-they could elicit nothing . " [He]763-he is either too clever for [us]1837-us or [an absolute idiot and fool]1838-an absolute idiot and fool , "[485-the judge] said [the Judge]485-the judge , wearily , at last , when [Groote]62-groote had gone out . " [We]1837-us had better commit [him]763-he to [Mazas]14-mazas and hold [him]763-he there in solitary confinement under [our]1837-us hands . "[317-the detective] " It was like this , [monsieur]1266-monsieur . When [we]1891-our were all seated , [I]798-i looked round , and did not at first see [[our]1891-our Italian]1892-our italian . " There was some reason for this , [I]0-i felt sure , although [I]0-i did not understand it immediately . "[0-i] Presently [I]0-i got at the hidden meaning There was a small piece of paper , rolled up or crumpled up into a ball , lying upon this table , and [the Italian]324-the italian wished , nay , was desperately anxious , to call [the lady]169-the lady 's attention to it . If [I]0-i had had any doubt of this , it was quite removed after [the man]175-the man had gone into [the inner room]810-the inner room . "[70-colonel papillon] Then [Colonel Papillon]70-colonel papillon rode off , and [the General]203-the general was driven to [the Boulevard des Capucines]916-the boulevard des capucines , having much to occupy [his]203-the general thoughts by the way . It did not greatly please [him]203-the general to have this story of [the Countess]340-the countess 's relations with [Quadling]91-quadling , as first hinted at by [the police]1514-the police , endorsed now by [[his]203-the general friend]729-his friend [Papillon]70-colonel papillon . Clearly [she]340-the countess had kept up [her]340-the countess acquaintance , [her]340-the countess intimacy to the very last : why otherwise should [she]340-the countess have received [him]91-quadling , alone , been closeted with [him]91-quadling for an hour or more on the very eve of [his]91-quadling flight ? It was a clandestine acquaintance too , or seemed so , for [Sir Charles]56-sir charles , although [a frequent visitor at [[her]340-the countess house]1563-her house]920-a frequent visitor at her house , had never met [Quadling]91-quadling [there]1288-there . What did it all mean ? And yet , what , after all , did it matter to [him]203-the general ? A good deal really more than [he]203-the general chose to admit to [himself]203-the general , even now , when closely questioning [his]203-the general secret heart . The fact was , [the Countess]340-the countess had made a very strong impression on [him]203-the general from the first . [He]203-the general had admired [her]340-the countess greatly during the past winter at [Rome]7-rome , but then it was only a passing fancy , as [he]203-the general thought,--the pleasant platonic flirtation of [a middle - aged man , who never expected to inspire or feel a great love]924-a middle - aged man , who never expected to inspire or feel a great love . Only now , when [he]203-the general had shared a serious trouble with [her]340-the countess , had passed through common difficulties and dangers , [he]203-the general was finding what accident may do -- how it may fan a first liking into a stronger flame . It was absurd , of course . [He]203-the general was fifty - one , [he]203-the general had weathered many trifling affairs of the heart , and here [he]203-the general was , bowled over at last , and by [a woman [he]203-the general was not certain was entitled to [his]203-the general respect]925-a woman he was not certain was entitled to his respect . What was [he]203-the general to do ? The answer came at once and unhesitatingly , as it would to [any other honest , chivalrous gentleman]926-any other honest , chivalrous gentleman . " By [George]108-george , [I]56-sir charles 'll stick to [her]340-the countess through thick and thin ! [I]56-sir charles 'll trust [her]340-the countess whatever happens or has happened , come what may . [Such a woman]2034-such a woman as that is above suspicion . [She]340-the countess _ must _ be straight . [I]56-sir charles should be a beast and [a blackguard double distilled to think anything else]2035-a blackguard double distilled to think anything else . [I]56-sir charles am sure [she]340-the countess can put all right with a word , can explain everything when [she]340-the countess chooses . [I]56-sir charles will wait till [she]340-the countess does . That first sweet kiss sealed the compact so quickly entered into between [them]963-them . And after that [she]961-you surrendered at discretion . There was no more hesitation or reluctance ; [she]961-you accepted [his]962-his love as [he]962-his had offered it , freely , with whole heart and soul , crept up under [his]962-his sheltering wing like a storm - beaten dove reëntering the nest , and there , cooing softly , " [[My]961-you knight]2058-my knight -- [[my]961-you own true knight]2059-my own true knight and [lord]2060-lord , "[961-you] yielded [herself]961-you willingly and unquestioningly to [his]962-his tender caresses . [They]963-them sat there , [these two]1973-these two , hand locked in hand , saying little , satisfied now to be with [each other]229-each other and [their]963-them new - found love . Why , [I]56-sir charles caught [him]56-sir charles trying -- but that reminds [me]56-sir charles -- [I]56-sir charles rescued this telegram from [his]56-sir charles clutches . "[56-sir charles] [He]56-sir charles took the little blue envelope from [his]56-sir charles breast pocket and handed it to [her]966-i , kissing the tips of [her]966-i fingers as [she]966-i took it from [him]56-sir charles . " Ah ! "[56-sir charles] A sudden ejaculation of dismay escaped [her]966-i , when , after rather carelessly tearing the message open , [she]966-i had glanced at it . " What is the matter ? "[56-sir charles] [he]56-sir charles asked in eager solicitude . " May [I]56-sir charles not know ? "[56-sir charles] [She]966-i made no offer to give [him]56-sir charles the telegram , and said in a faltering voice , and with much hesitation of manner , " [I]966-i do not know . [I]966-i hardly think -- of course [I]966-i do not like to withhold anything , not now . And yet , this is a business which concerns [me]966-i only , [I]966-i am afraid . [I]966-i ought not to drag [you]56-sir charles into it . "[966-i] " What concerns [you]56-sir charles is very much [my]966-i business , too . [I]966-i do not wish to force [your]56-sir charles confidence , still-- "[966-i] [She]966-i gave [him]56-sir charles the telegram quite obediently , with a little sigh of relief , glad to realize now , for the first time after many years , that there was [some one]1386-some one to give [her]966-i orders and take the burden of trouble off [her]966-i shoulders . [He]56-sir charles read it , but did not understand it in the least . [It]968-i ran : " [I]968-i must see [you]56-sir charles immediately , and beg [you]56-sir charles will come . [You]56-sir charles will find [Hortense]80-hortense petitpré here . [She]80-hortense petitpré is giving trouble . [You]56-sir charles only can deal with [her]80-hortense petitpré . Do not delay . " [He]99-ripaldi -- [he]99-ripaldi -- oh , [Charles]56-sir charles , [I]56-sir charles shall have to go . Anything would be better than [his]99-ripaldi coming here . "[56-sir charles] [The General]203-the general was fairly staggered at this unexpected blow . Floçon]58-m. floçon , who promptly tried to turn it to good account . " Come , [M. le Général]77-m. le général , "[203-the general] [he]203-the general said , with much assumed _ bonhomie _ . [He]203-the general did not like it at all ; yet what could [he]203-the general do ? [Prudence]121-prudence gained the day , and after a struggle [he]203-the general decided to submit , lest worse might befall [him]203-the general . There was , in truth , worse to be encountered . It was very irksome to be in the power of [this now domineering little man on [his]1033-this now domineering little man on his own ground own ground]1033-this now domineering little man on his own ground , and eager to show [his]1033-this now domineering little man on his own ground power . " It is here ! "[58-m. floçon] said [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon , as [he]58-m. floçon turned the handle unceremoniously without knocking . " Enter . " [Baume]122-baume , "[247-the chief] said [the Chief]247-the chief , shortly , " [I]247-the chief wish to leave [this gentleman]1620-this gentleman with [you]122-baume . "[56-sir charles] [Sir Charles]56-sir charles nodded carelessly , took the first chair that offered , and sat down by the fire . [He]56-sir charles was to all intents and purposes in [custody]1259-custody , and [he]56-sir charles examined [[his]56-sir charles gaoler]1046-his gaoler at first wrathfully , then curiously , struck with [his]1046-his gaoler rather strange figure and appearance . [Baume]122-baume , as [the Chief]247-the chief had called [him]122-baume , was [a short , thick - set man with a great shock head sunk in low between a pair of enormous shoulders , betokening great physical strength]1048-a short , thick - set man with a great shock head sunk in low between a pair of enormous shoulders , betokening great physical strength ; [he]122-baume stood on very thin but greatly twisted bow legs , and the quaintness of [his]122-baume figure was emphasized by the short black blouse or smock - frock [he]122-baume wore over [his]122-baume other clothes like [a French artisan]1049-a french artisan . [He]122-baume was [a man of few words , and those not the most polite in tone]1050-a man of few words , and those not the most polite in tone , for when [the General]203-the general began with a banal remark about the weather , [M. Baume]122-baume replied , shortly : " [I]122-baume wish to have no talk ; "[122-baume] and when [Sir Charles]56-sir charles pulled out [his]56-sir charles cigarette - case , as [he]56-sir charles did almost automatically from time to time when in any situation of annoyance or perplexity , [Baume]122-baume raised [his]122-baume hand warningly and grunted : " Not allowed . "[122-baume] " Then [I]203-the general 'll be hanged if [I]203-the general do n't smoke in spite of [every man jack of [you]56-sir charles]2143-every man jack of you ! "[203-the general] cried [the General]203-the general , hotly , rising from [his]203-the general seat and speaking unconsciously in English . " What 's that ? "[122-baume] asked [Baume]122-baume , gruffly . [He]122-baume was [one of [the detective staff]1054-the detective staff]1053-one of the detective staff , and was only doing [his]122-baume duty according to [his]122-baume lights , and [he]122-baume said so with such an injured air that [the General]203-the general was pacified , laughed , and relapsed into silence without lighting [his]203-the general cigarette . The time ran on , from minutes into nearly an hour , a very trying wait for [Sir Charles]56-sir charles . There is always something irritating in doing antechamber work , in kicking [one]1283-one 's heels in [the waiting - room of [any functionary or official]1058-any functionary or official]1057-the waiting - room of any functionary or official , high or low , and [the General]203-the general found it hard to possess [himself]203-the general in patience , when [he]203-the general thought [he]203-the general was being thus ignominiously treated by [a man like [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon]1060-a man like m. floçon . All the time , too , [he]203-the general was worrying [himself]203-the general about [the Countess]340-the countess , wondering first how [she]340-the countess had fared ; next , where [she]340-the countess was just then ; last of all , and longest , whether it was possible for [her]340-the countess to be mixed up in anything compromising or criminal . Suddenly an electric bell struck in [the room]461-the room . There was a table telephone at [Baume]122-baume 's elbow ; [he]203-the general took up the handle , put the tube to [his]203-the general mouth and ear , got [his]203-the general message answered , and then , rising , said abruptly to [Sir Charles]56-sir charles : " Come . "[203-the general] When [the General]203-the general was at last ushered into the presence of [the Chief of [the Detective Police]2077-the detective police]2076-the chief of the detective police , [he]203-the general found to [his]203-the general satisfaction that [Colonel Papillon]70-colonel papillon was also [there]1288-there , and at [M. " [You]203-the general will , [I]75-m. beaumont le hardi trust , pardon [us]1068-the two englishmen , [M. le Général]77-m. le général , for having detained [you]203-the general here and so long . But there were , as [we]1068-the two englishmen thought , good and sufficient reasons . If those have now lost some of [their]2144-their cogency , [we]1068-the two englishmen still stand by [our]1068-the two englishmen action as having been justifiable in the execution of [our]1068-the two englishmen duty . [We]1068-the two englishmen are now willing to let [you]203-the general go free , because -- because-- "[75-m. beaumont le hardi] " [We]1068-the two englishmen have caught [the person]1690-the person , [the lady [you]203-the general helped to escape]2146-the lady you helped to escape , "[317-the detective] blurted out [the detective]317-the detective , unable to resist making the point . " [The Countess]78-the countess ? Is [she]78-the countess [here]1265-here , in custody ? Never ! "[317-the detective] " [She]78-the countess is English by birth , and whether or no , [she]78-the countess is [a woman]375-a woman , [a high - bred lady]2155-a high - bred lady ; and it is abominable , unheard - of , to subject [her]78-the countess to such monstrous treatment , "[203-the general] said [the General]203-the general . " But [these gentlemen]2156-these gentlemen declare that [they]2156-these gentlemen are fully warranted , that [she]78-the countess has put [herself]78-the countess in the wrong -- greatly , culpably in the wrong . "[203-the general] " [I]203-the general do n't believe it ! "[203-the general] cried [the General]203-the general , indignantly . " Not from [these chaps]2157-these chaps , [a pack of idiots]2158-a pack of idiots , always on the wrong tack ! [I]203-the general do n't believe a word , not if [they]2157-these chaps swear . "[203-the general] " But [they]2157-these chaps have documentary evidence -- papers of the most damaging kind against [her]78-the countess . "[203-the general] " Where ? How ? "[203-the general] " [He]95-jack -- [M. le Juge]61-m. le juge -- has been showing [me]203-the general a note - book ; "[203-the general] and [the General]203-the general 's eyes , following [Jack Papillon]95-jack 's , were directed to a small _ carnet _ , or memorandum - book , which [the Judge]485-the judge , interpreting the glance , was tapping significantly with [his]485-the judge finger . Then [the Judge]485-the judge said blandly , " It is easy to perceive that [you]203-the general protest , M. le Général , against [that lady]1399-that lady 's arrest . Is it so ? Well , [we]2160-we are not called upon to justify it to [you]203-the general , not in the very least . But [we]2160-we are dealing with [a brave man]2161-a brave man , [a gentleman]500-a gentleman , [an officer of high rank and consideration]2163-an officer of high rank and consideration , and [you]203-the general shall know things that [we]2160-we are not bound to tell , to [you]203-the general or to [any one]1352-any one . "[485-the judge] " First , "[485-the judge] [he]485-the judge continued , holding up the note - book , " do [you]203-the general know what this is ? Have [you]203-the general ever seen it before ? "[485-the judge] " [Ripaldi]99-ripaldi ? " Ah ! now [I]203-the general understand . "[203-the general] " [You]485-the judge had heard of it , then ? In what connection ? " [I]203-the general now understand , "[203-the general] replied [the General]203-the general , perfectly on [his]203-the general guard , " why the note - book was familiar to [me]203-the general . [I]203-the general had seen it in [that man]2114-that man 's hands in [the waiting - room]269-the waiting - room . [He]2114-that man was writing in it . "[203-the general] " Indeed ? A favourite occupation evidently . [He]2114-that man was fond of confiding in that note - book , and committed to it much that [he]2114-that man never expected would see the light -- [his]2114-that man movements , intentions , ideas , even [his]2114-that man inmost thoughts . The book -- which [he]2114-that man no doubt lost inadvertently is very incriminating to [himself]2114-that man and [[his]2114-that man friends]1558-his friends . "[203-the general] " What do [you]485-the judge imply ? "[56-sir charles] hastily inquired [Sir Charles]56-sir charles . " Simply that it is on that which is written here that [we]2171-our base one part , perhaps the strongest , of [our]2171-our case against [the Countess]78-the countess . It is strangely but convincingly corroborative of [our]2171-our suspicions against [her]78-the countess . "[56-sir charles] " May [I]203-the general look at it for [myself]203-the general ? "[203-the general] went on [the General]203-the general in a tone of contemptuous disbelief . " It is in Italian . Perhaps [you]203-the general can read that language ? If not , [I]485-the judge have translated the most important passages , "[485-the judge] said [the Judge]485-the judge , offering some other papers . " Thank [you]203-the general ; if [you]203-the general will permit [me]485-the judge , [I]485-the judge should prefer to look at the original ; "[485-the judge] and [the General]203-the general , without more ado , stretched out [his]203-the general hand and took the note - book . What [he]203-the general read there , as [he]203-the general quickly scanned its pages , shall be told in the next chapter . It will be seen that there were things written that looked very damaging to [[his]203-the general dear friend]1082-his dear friend , [Sabine Castagneto]111-sabine . [Ripaldi]99-ripaldi 's diary -- its ownership plainly shown by the record of [his]99-ripaldi name in full , [Natale Ripaldi]73-ripaldi , inside the cover -- was a commonplace note - book bound in shabby drab cloth , its edges and corners strengthened with some sort of white metal . The pages were of coarse paper , lined blue and red , and they were dog - eared and smirched as though they had been constantly turned over and used . The earlier entries were little more than a record of work to do or done . " Jan. 11 . To call at Café di [Roma]40-roma , 12.30 . [Beppo]123-beppo will meet [me]127-x. . "[127-x.] Jan. 13 . Traced M. L. Last employed as a model at [S. 's studio]1083-s. 's studio , Palazzo B. " Jan. 15 . There is trouble brewing at [the Circulo Bonafede]2172-the circulo bonafede ; [Louvaih]124-louvaih , [Malatesta]125-malatesta , and [the Englishman Sprot]55-the englishman , have joined [it]2172-the circulo bonafede . All are [noted Anarchists]2173-noted anarchists . "[129-q.] Jan. 20 . Mem . , pay Trattore . [The Bestia]126-the bestia will not wait . [X.]127-x. is also pressing , and [Mariuccia]128-mariuccia . Situation tightens . " Jan. 23 . Ordered to watch [Q.]129-q. Could [I]127-x. work [him]129-q. ? No . Strong doubts of [his]129-q. solvency . "[127-x.] Feb. 10 , 11 , 12 . After Q. No grounds yet . " Feb. 27 . [Q.]129-q. keeps up good appearance . Any mistake ? Shall [I]127-x. try [him]129-q. ? Sorely pressed . [X.]127-x. threatens [me]127-x. with Prefettura . "[127-x.] March 1 . [Q.]129-q. in difficulties . Out late every night . Is playing high ; poor luck . " March 3 . Q. means mischief . Preparing for a start ? "[127-x.] March 10 . Saw Q. about , here , there , everywhere . " Then followed a brief account of [Quadling]91-quadling 's movements on the day before [his]91-quadling departure from [Rome]7-rome , very much as they have been described in a previous chapter . These were made mostly in the form of reflections , conjectures , hopes , and fears ; hurry - scurry of pursuit had no doubt broken the immediate record of events , and these had been entered next day in [the train]145-the train . "[127-x.] March 17 ( the day previous ) . [He]129-q. has not shown up . [I]0-i thought to see [him]129-q. at the buffet at [Genoa]41-genoa . [The conductor]1234-the conductor took [him]129-q. [his]129-q. coffee to [the car]144-the car . [I]0-i hoped to have begun an acquaintance . " 12.30 . Breakfasted at [Turin]37-turin . [Q.]129-q. did not come to table . Found [him]129-q. hanging about [outside restaurant]2175-outside restaurant . Spoke ; got short reply . Wishes to avoid observation , [I]0-i suppose . "[0-i] But [he]129-q. speaks to [others]777-others . [He]129-q. has claimed acquaintance with [madame 's lady 's maid]1087-madame 's lady 's maid , and [he]129-q. wants to speak to [the mistress]1088-the mistress . ' Tell [her]1088-the mistress [I]0-i must speak to [her]1088-the mistress , ' [I]0-i heard [him]129-q. say , as [I]0-i passed close to [them]1089-i . Then [they]1089-i separated hurriedly . " At [Modane]15-modane [he]129-q. came to [the Douane]42-the douane , and afterwards into [the restaurant]148-the restaurant . [He]129-q. bowed across the table to [the lady]169-the lady . [She]169-the lady hardly recognized [him]129-q. , which is odd . Of course [she]169-the lady must know [him]129-q. ; then why-- ? There is something between [them]1089-i , and [the maid]1308-the maid is in it . "[1089-i] What shall _ [I]0-i _ do ? [I]0-i could spoil any game of theirs if [I]0-i stepped in . What are [they]1089-i after ? [His]129-q. money , no doubt . " So am [I]1089-i ; [I]1089-i have the best right to it , for [I]1089-i can do most for [him]129-q. . [He]129-q. is absolutely in [my]1089-i power , and [he]129-q. 'll see that -- [he]129-q. 's no fool-- directly [he]129-q. knows who [I]1089-i am , and why [I]1089-i 'm [here]1265-here . It will be worth [his]129-q. while to buy [me]1089-i off , if [I]1089-i 'm ready to sell [myself]1089-i , and [my]1089-i duty , and the Prefettura -- and why should n't [I]1089-i ? What better can [I]1089-i do ? Shall [I]1089-i ever have such a chance again ? Twenty , thirty , forty thousand lire , more , even , at one stroke ; why , it 's a fortune ! [I]1089-i could go to [the Republic]2180-the republic , to [America]43-america , [North]44-north or [South]45-south , send for [Mariuccia--]130-mariuccia-- no , _ cos petto ! _ [I]1089-i will continue free ! [I]1089-i will spend the money on [myself]1089-i , as [I]1089-i alone will have earned it , and at such risk . "[1089-i] [I]0-i have worked it out thus : " [I]0-i will go to [him]129-q. at the very last , just before [we]2181-we are reaching [Paris]1-paris . Tell [him]129-q. , threaten [him]129-q. with arrest , then give [him]129-q. [his]129-q. chance of escape . No fear that [he]129-q. wo n't accept it ; [he]129-q. _ must _ , whatever [he]129-q. may have settled with [the others]1394-the others . [_ Altro]131-_ altro ! _ [I]0-i snap [my]0-i fingers at [them]1853-these two women . [He]129-q. has most to fear from [me]0-i . "[0-i] The next entries were made after some interval , a long interval , --no doubt , after the terrible deed had been done,--and the words were traced with trembling fingers , so that the writing was most irregular and scarcely legible . " Ugh ! [I]1089-i am still trembling with horror and fear . [I]1089-i can not get it out of [my]1089-i mind ; [I]1089-i never shall . Why , what tempted [me]1089-i ? How could [I]1089-i bring [myself]1089-i to do it ? "[1089-i] But for [these two women]1853-these two women -- [they]1853-these two women are [fiends]1091-fiends , [furies]1092-furies -- it would never have been necessary . Now [one of [them]1853-these two women]1990-one of them has escaped , and the other-- [she]1990-one of them is here , so cold - blooded , so self - possessed and quiet -- who would have thought it of [her]1990-one of them ? That [she]1990-one of them , [a lady of rank and high breeding , gentle , delicate , tender - hearted . Tender]1094-a lady of rank and high breeding , gentle , delicate , tender - hearted . tender ? [the fiend]1095-the fiend ! Oh , shall [I]0-i ever forget [her]1990-one of them ? " And now [she]1990-one of them has [me]1095-the fiend in [her]1990-one of them power ! But have [I]1095-the fiend not [her]1990-one of them also ? [We]2183-we are in [the same boat]2184-the same boat -- [we]2183-we must sink or swim , together . [We]2183-we are equally bound , [I]1095-the fiend to [her]1990-one of them , [she]1990-one of them to [me]1095-the fiend . What are [we]2183-we to do ? How shall [we]2183-we meet inquiry ? _ [Santissima Donna]132-santissima donna ! _ why did [I]1095-the fiend not risk it , and climb out like [the maid]1308-the maid ? It was terrible for the moment , but the worst would have been over , and now-- "[1095-the fiend] There was yet more , scribbled in the same faltering , agitated handwriting , and from the context the entries had been made in [the waiting - room of [the railroad station]1097-the railroad station]1096-the waiting - room of the railroad station . " [I]1095-the fiend must attract [her]1990-one of them attention . [She]1990-one of them will not look [my]1095-the fiend way . [I]1095-the fiend want [her]1990-one of them to understand that [I]1095-the fiend have something special to say to [her]1990-one of them , and that , as [we]1100-we are forbidden to speak , [I]1095-the fiend am writing it herein -- that [she]1990-one of them must contrive to take the book from [me]1095-the fiend and read unobserved . "[1095-the fiend] _ Cos petto ! _ [she]1098-she is stupid ! Has fear dazed [her]1098-she entirely ? No matter , [I]0-i will set it all down . " Now followed what [the police]1514-the police deemed such damaging evidence . "[1099-countess] [Countess]1099-countess . Remember . Silence -- absolute silence . Not a word as to who [I]0-i am , or what is common knowledge to [us]1100-we both . It is done . That can not be undone . Be brave , resolute ; admit nothing . Stick to it that [you]1101-you know nothing , heard nothing . Deny that [you]1101-you knew _ [him]1102-him _ , or [me]0-i . Swear [you]1101-you slept soundly the night through , make some excuse , say [you]1101-you were drugged , anything , only be on [your]1101-you guard , and say nothing about [me]0-i . [I]0-i warn [you]1101-you . Leave [me]0-i alone . Or -- but [your]1101-you interests are [my]0-i interests ; [we]1100-we must stand or fall together . Afterwards [I]0-i will meet [you]1101-you -- [I]0-i _ must _ meet [you]1101-you somewhere . If [we]1100-we miss at [the station front]1103-the station front , write to [me]0-i Poste Restante , [Grand Hôtel]133-grand hôtel , and give [me]0-i an address . This is imperative . Once more , silence and discretion . " This ended the writing in the note - book , and the whole perusal occupied [Sir Charles]56-sir charles from fifteen to twenty minutes , during which [the French officials]593-the french officials watched [his]56-sir charles face closely , and [[his]56-sir charles friend]729-his friend [Colonel Papillon]70-colonel papillon anxiously . But [the General]203-the general 's mask was impenetrable , and at the end of [his]203-the general reading [he]203-the general turned back to read and re - read many pages , holding the book to the light , and seeming to examine the contents very curiously . "[133-grand hôtel] Well ? " said [the Judge]485-the judge at last , when [he]485-the judge met [the General]203-the general 's eye . "[133-grand hôtel] Do [you]1104-you lay great store by this evidence ? " asked [the General]203-the general in a calm , dispassionate voice . "[1104-you] Is it not natural that [we]1100-we should ? Is it not strongly , conclusively incriminating ? " "[1104-you] It would be so , of course , if it were to be depended upon . But as to that [I]0-i have [my]0-i doubts , and grave doubts . " "[0-i] Bah ! " interposed [the detective]317-the detective ; "[0-i] that is mere conjecture , mere assertion . Why should not the book be believed ? It is perfectly genuine-- " "[1255-sir] Wait , [sir]1255-sir , " said [the General]203-the general , raising [his]203-the general hand . "[1255-sir] Have [you]1255-sir not noticed -- surely it can not have escaped so astute [a police functionary]1106-a police functionary -- that the entries are not all in the same handwriting ? " "[1255-sir] What ! Oh , that is too absurd ! " cried both [the officials]263-the officials in a breath . [They]263-the officials saw at once that if this discovery were admitted to be an absolute fact , the whole drift of [their]263-the officials conclusions must be changed . "[1255-sir] Examine the book for [yourselves]1255-sir . To [my]0-i mind it is perfectly clear and beyond all question , " insisted [Sir Charles]56-sir charles . "[0-i] [I]0-i am quite positive that the last pages were written by a different hand from the first . " For several minutes both [the Judge]485-the judge and [the detective]317-the detective pored over the note - book , examining page after page , shaking [their]263-the officials heads , and declining to accept the evidence of [their]263-the officials eyes . "[0-i] [I]0-i can not see it , " said [the Judge]485-the judge at last ; adding reluctantly , "[0-i] No doubt there is a difference , but it is to be explained . " "[0-i] Quite so , " put in [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon . "[0-i] When [he]1107-he wrote the early part , [he]1107-he was calm and collected ; the last entries , so straggling , so ragged , and so badly written , were made when [he]1107-he was fresh from the crime , excited , upset , [little master of [himself]1107-he]1108-little master of himself . Naturally [he]1107-he would use a different hand . " "[1107-he] Or [he]1107-he would wish to disguise it . It was likely [he]1107-he would so wish , " further remarked [the Judge]485-the judge . "[1107-he] [You]1109-you admit , then , that there is a difference ? " argued [the General]203-the general , shrewdly . "[1109-you] But there is more than a disguise . The best disguise leaves certain unchangeable features . Some letters , capital G 's , H 's , and others , will betray [themselves]1110-themselves through the best disguise . [I]0-i know what [I]0-i am saying . [I]0-i have studied the subject of handwriting ; it interests [me]0-i . These are the work of two different hands . Call in [an expert]1111-an expert ; [you]1112-you will find [I]0-i am right . " "[1111-an expert] Well , well , " said [the Judge]485-the judge , after a pause , "[1111-an expert] let [us]1113-us grant [your]1112-you position for the moment . What do [you]1112-you deduce ? What do [you]1112-you infer therefrom ? " "[1112-you] Surely [you]1109-you can see what follows -- what this leads [us]1113-us to ? " said [Sir Charles]56-sir charles , rather disdainfully . "[0-i] [I]0-i have formed an opinion -- yes , but [I]0-i should like to see if it coincides with [yours]1109-you . [You]1109-you think-- " "[1109-you] [I]0-i know , " corrected [the General]203-the general . "[1109-you] [I]0-i know that , as [two persons]1114-two persons wrote in that book , either it is not [Ripaldi]73-ripaldi 's book , or the last of [them]1114-two persons was not [Ripaldi]73-ripaldi . [I]0-i saw [the last writer]1115-the last writer at [his]1115-the last writer work , saw [him]1115-the last writer with [my]0-i own eyes . Yet [he]73-ripaldi did not write with [Ripaldi]73-ripaldi 's hand-- this is incontestable , [I]0-i am sure of it , [I]0-i will swear it -- ergo , [he]73-ripaldi is not [Ripaldi]73-ripaldi . " "[73-ripaldi] But [you]1109-you should have known this at the time , " interjected [M. Floçon]58-m. floçon , fiercely . "[1109-you] Why did [you]1109-you not discover the change of identity ? [You]1109-you should have seen that this was not [Ripaldi]73-ripaldi . " "[73-ripaldi] Pardon [me]0-i . [I]0-i did not know [the man]175-the man . [I]0-i had not noticed [him]175-the man particularly on the journey . There was no reason why [I]0-i should . [I]0-i had no communication , no dealings , with any of [[my]0-i fellow passengers]1117-my fellow passengers except [[my]0-i brother]1331-my brother and [the Countess]340-the countess . " "[0-i] But some of [the others]1394-the others would surely have remarked the change ? " went on [the Judge]485-the judge , greatly puzzled . "[1394-the others] That alone seems enough to condemn [your]1109-you theory , [M. le General]1121-m. le general . " "[0-i] [I]0-i take [my]0-i stand on fact , not theory , " stoutly maintained [Sir Charles]56-sir charles , "[0-i] and [I]0-i am satisfied [I]0-i am right . " "[0-i] But if that was not [Ripaldi]73-ripaldi , who was it ? Who would wish to masquerade in [his]73-ripaldi dress and character , to make entries of that sort , as if under [his]73-ripaldi hand ? " "[73-ripaldi] Some one determined to divert suspicion from [himself]73-ripaldi to others-- " "[73-ripaldi] But stay -- does [he]73-ripaldi not plainly confess [his]73-ripaldi own guilt ? " "[73-ripaldi] What matter if [he]73-ripaldi is not [Ripaldi]73-ripaldi ? Directly the inquiry was over , [he]73-ripaldi could steal away and resume [his]73-ripaldi own personality -- that of [a man supposed to be dead]1122-a man supposed to be dead , and therefore safe from all interference and future pursuit . [They]1124-they fought , no doubt , and [Quadling]91-quadling killed [him]73-ripaldi , possibly in self - defence . [He]73-ripaldi would have said so , but in [his]73-ripaldi peculiar position as [an absconding defaulter]1125-an absconding defaulter [he]73-ripaldi did not dare . " It was the usual crowd of [sightseers]2228-sightseers passing slowly before the plate glass of this , [the most terrible shop - front in [the world]409-the world]2229-the most terrible shop - front in the world , where the goods exposed , the merchandise , are hideous corpses laid out in rows upon the marble slabs , the battered , tattered remnants of [outraged humanity , insulted by the most terrible indignities in death]2231-outraged humanity , insulted by the most terrible indignities in death . Strangest of all , [the murderer]350-the murderer [himself]350-the murderer , [the doer of the fell deed]2245-the doer of the fell deed , comes here , to [the very spot where [[his]350-the murderer victim]2247-his victim lies stark and reproachful , and stares at it spellbound , fascinated , filled more with remorse , perchance , than fear at the risk [he]350-the murderer runs]2246-the very spot where his victim lies stark and reproachful , and stares at it spellbound , fascinated , filled more with remorse , perchance , than fear at the risk he runs . So common is this trait , that in mysterious murder cases [the police of [Paris]1-paris]2248-the police of paris keep [a disguised officer among [the crowd]2250-the crowd at [the Morgue]1132-the morgue]2249-a disguised officer among the crowd at the morgue , and have thereby made many memorable arrests . "[1150-many people in yonder] This way , [gentlemen]1245-gentlemen , this way ; " and [the keeper of the Morgue]2252-the keeper of the morgue led [the party]788-the party through [one or two rooms]2254-one or two rooms into [the inner and back recesses of [the buildings]2256-the buildings]2255-the inner and back recesses of the buildings . It was behind the scenes of [the Morgue]1132-the morgue , and [they]1153-they were made free of [its]1132-the morgue most gruesome secrets as [they]1153-they passed along . The temperature had suddenly fallen far below freezing - point , and the icy cold chilled to the very marrow . Still worse was an all - pervading , acrid odour of artificially suspended animal decay . The cold - air process , that latest of scientific contrivances to arrest the waste of tissue , has now been applied at [the Morgue]1132-the morgue to preserve and keep the bodies fresh , and allow [them]1153-they to be for a longer time exposed than when running water was the only aid . There are , moreover , many specially contrived refrigerating chests , in which those still unrecognized corpses are laid by for months , to be dragged out , if needs be , like carcasses of meat . " The request was not unnecessary , for when [Colonel Papillon]70-colonel papillon went forward , and , putting [his]70-colonel papillon hand on [a man]237-a man 's shoulder , saying , "[91-quadling] [Mr. Quadling]91-quadling , [I]0-i think , " [the police officer]2268-the police officer was scarcely able to restrain [his]70-colonel papillon surprise . [The person thus challenged]2269-the person thus challenged was very unlike [any one [he]70-colonel papillon had seen before that day]2270-any one he had seen before that day , [Ripaldi]73-ripaldi most of all . The moustache was gone , the clothes were entirely changed ; a pair of dark green spectacles helped the disguise . It was strange indeed that [Papillon]70-colonel papillon had known [him]91-quadling ; but at the moment of recognition [Quadling]91-quadling had removed [his]91-quadling glasses , no doubt that [he]91-quadling might the better examine the object of [his]91-quadling visit to [the Morgue]1132-the morgue , that gruesome record of [his]91-quadling own fell handiwork . " There was no escaping now , and with a poor attempt at bravado [the stranger]2273-the stranger was led away . "[0-i] Now , [Colonel Papillon]70-colonel papillon , look at [him]1167-him well .
