" [They]1170-your other men gave [the wretched man]2274-the wretched man but scant consideration , and in less than three minutes had visited every pocket , examined every secret receptacle , and practically turned [him]2274-the wretched man inside out . After this there could no longer be any doubt of [his]2274-the wretched man identity , still less of [his]2274-the wretched man complicity in the crime . First among the many damning evidences of [his]2274-the wretched man guilt was the missing pocketbook of [the porter of [the sleeping - car]143-the sleeping - car]2275-the porter of the sleeping - car . Within was the train card and [the passengers]221-the passengers ' tickets , all the papers which [the man Groote]2278-the man groote had lost so unaccountably . [They]1170-your other men had , of course , been stolen from [[his]2274-the wretched man person]2279-his person with the obvious intention of impeding the inquiry into the murder . Next , in another inner pocket was [Quadling]91-quadling 's own wallet , with [his]91-quadling own visiting - cards , several letters addressed to [him]91-quadling by name ; above all , a thick sheaf of bank - notes of all nationalities -- English , French , Italian , and amounting in total value to several thousands of pounds . "[134-la pêche] Well , do [you]0-i still deny ? Bah ! it is childish , useless , mere waste of breath . At last [we]1171-we have penetrated the mystery . [You]0-i may as well confess . " During the events just recorded , which occupied a good hour , [the police agents]2291-the police agents had time to go and come from [the Rue Bellechasse]38-rue bellechasse . " In [the fiacre Hortense Petitpré]2310-the fiacre hortense petitpré talked on with such incessant abuse , virulent and violent , of [Quadling]91-quadling , that [her]1197-her charges were neither precise nor intelligible . It was not until [she]1197-her appeared before [M. Beaumont le Hardi]75-m. beaumont le hardi , and was handled with great dexterity by [that practised examiner]2311-that practised examiner , that [her]1197-her story took definite form . What [she]1197-her had to say will be best told in the clear , formal language of the official disposition . [The witness inculpated]2312-the witness inculpated stated : "[1197-her] [She]1197-her was named [Aglaé Hortense Petitpré]80-hortense petitpré , thirty - four years of age , [a Frenchwoman]1198-a frenchwoman , born in [Paris]1-paris , [Rue de Vincennes]50-rue de vincennes No . 374 . Was engaged by [the Contessa Castagneto]120-the contessa castagneto , November 19 , 189 - - , in [Rome]7-rome , as [[lady]1199-lady 's maid]1200-lady 's maid , and there , at [[[her]1197-her mistress]1304-her mistress 's domicile]1202-her mistress 's domicile , became acquainted with [the Sieur Francis Quadling]91-quadling , [a banker of [the Via Condotti]51-the via condotti , [Rome]7-rome]1203-a banker of the via condotti , rome . " [Quadling]91-quadling had pretensions to the hand of [the Countess]340-the countess , and sought , by bribes and entreaties , to interest [witness]2314-witness in [his]91-quadling suit . [Witness]138-witness often spoke of [him]91-quadling in complimentary terms to [[her]340-the countess mistress]1304-her mistress , who was not very favourably disposed towards [him]91-quadling . "[91-quadling] One afternoon ( two days before the murder ) [Quadling]91-quadling paid a lengthened visit to [the Countess]340-the countess . [Witness]138-witness did not hear what occurred , but [Quadling]91-quadling came out much distressed , and again urged [her]340-the countess to speak to [the Countess]340-the countess . [He]91-quadling had heard of the approaching departure of [the lady]169-the lady from [Rome]7-rome , but said nothing of [his]91-quadling own intentions . " [Witness]138-witness was much surprised to find [him]91-quadling in [the sleeping - car]143-the sleeping - car , but had no talk to [him]91-quadling till the following morning , when [he]91-quadling asked [her]340-the countess to obtain an interview for [him]91-quadling with [the Countess]340-the countess , and promised a large reward . In making this offer [he]91-quadling produced a wallet and exhibited a very large number of notes . "[138-witness] [Witness]138-witness was unable to persuade [the Countess]340-the countess , although [she]340-the countess returned to the subject frequently . [Witness]138-witness so informed [Quadling]91-quadling , who then spoke to [the lady]169-the lady , but was coldly received . " During the journey witness thought much over the situation . Admitted that the sight of [Quadling]91-quadling 's money had greatly disturbed [her]340-the countess , but , although pressed , would not say when the first idea of robbing [him]91-quadling took possession of [her]340-the countess . ( Note by Judge -- That [she]340-the countess had resolved to do so is , however , perfectly clear , and the conclusion is borne out by [her]340-the countess acts . It was [she]340-the countess who secured [the Countess]340-the countess 's medicine bottle ; [she]340-the countess , beyond doubt , who drugged [the porter at [Laroche]2-laroche]2319-the porter at laroche . In no other way can [her]138-witness presence in [the sleeping - car between [Laroche]2-laroche and [Paris]1-paris]2320-the sleeping - car between laroche and paris be accounted for - presence which [she]138-witness does not deny . ) "[138-witness] [Witness]138-witness at last reluctantly confessed that [she]138-witness entered the compartment where the murder was committed , and at a critical moment . An affray was actually in progress between [the Italian Ripaldi]99-ripaldi and [the incriminated man Quadling]1209-the incriminated man quadling , but [the witness]510-the witness arrived as the last fatal blow was struck by [the latter]223-the latter . " [She]138-witness saw it struck , and saw [the victim]176-the victim fall lifeless on the floor . "[2314-witness] [Witness]2314-witness declared [she]138-witness was so terrified [she]138-witness could at first utter no cry , nor call for help , and before [she]138-witness could recover [herself]138-witness [the murderer]350-the murderer threatened [her]138-witness with the ensanguined knife . [She]138-witness threw [herself]138-witness on [her]138-witness knees , imploring pity , but [the man Quadling]1131-the man quadling told [her]138-witness that [she]138-witness was [an eye - witness]1215-an eye - witness , and could take [him]1131-the man quadling to the guillotine,--she also must die . " [Witness]138-witness at last prevailed on [him]91-quadling to spare [her]138-witness life , but only on condition that [she]138-witness would leave [the car]144-the car . [He]91-quadling indicated the window as the only way of escape ; but on this for a long time [she]138-witness refused to venture , declaring that it was only to exchange one form of death for another . Then , as [Quadling]91-quadling again threatened to stab [her]138-witness , [she]138-witness was compelled to accept this last chance , never hoping to win out alive . "[1131-the man quadling] With [Quadling]91-quadling 's assistance , however , [she]138-witness succeeded in climbing out through the window and in gaining the roof . [He]91-quadling had told [her]138-witness to wait for the first occasion when [the train]145-the train slackened speed to leave [it]145-the train and shift for [herself]138-witness . With this intention [he]91-quadling gave [her]138-witness a thousand francs , and bade [her]138-witness never show [herself]138-witness again . " [Witness]138-witness descended from [the train]145-the train not far from [the small station of [Villeneuve]52-villeneuve on the line]2324-the small station of villeneuve on the line , and there took [the local train]2325-the local train for [Paris]1-paris . Landed at [the Lyons Station]53-the lyons station , [she]138-witness heard of the inquiry in progress , and then , waiting outside , saw [Quadling]91-quadling disguised as [the Italian]324-the italian leave in company with [another man]1606-another man . [She]138-witness followed and marked [Quadling]91-quadling down , meaning to denounce [him]91-quadling on the first opportunity . [Quadling]91-quadling , however , on issuing from [the restaurant]148-the restaurant , had accosted [her]138-witness , and at once offered [her]138-witness a further sum of five thousand francs as the price of silence , and [she]138-witness had gone with [him]91-quadling to [the Hôtel Ivoire]2292-the hôtel ivoire , where [she]138-witness was to receive the sum . [Quadling]91-quadling had paid it , but on one condition , that [she]138-witness would remain at [the Hotel Ivoire]2330-the hotel ivoire until the following day . Apparently [he]91-quadling had distrusted [her]138-witness , for [he]91-quadling had contrived to lock [her]138-witness into [[her]138-witness compartment]215-her compartment . As [she]138-witness did not choose to be so imprisoned , [she]138-witness summoned assistance , and was at length released by [the police]1514-the police . "[91-quadling] This was the substance of [Hortense Petitpré]80-hortense petitpré 's deposition , and it was corroborated in many small details . When [she]80-hortense petitpré appeared before [the Judge]485-the judge , with whom [Sir Charles Collingham]56-sir charles and [Colonel Papillon]70-colonel papillon were seated , [the former]1218-the former at once pointed out that [she]80-hortense petitpré was wearing a dark mantle trimmed with the same sort of passementerie as that picked up in [the sleeping - car]143-the sleeping - car . [L'Envoi Quadling]139-quadling was in due course brought before [the Court of Assize]1220-the court of assize and tried for [his]139-quadling life . There was no sort of doubt of [his]139-quadling guilt , and [the jury]1221-the jury so found , but , having regard to certain extenuating circumstances , [they]1221-the jury recommended [him]139-quadling to mercy . The chief of these was [Quadling]139-quadling 's positive assurance that [he]139-quadling had been first attacked by [Ripaldi]99-ripaldi ; [he]139-quadling declared that [the Italian detective]1222-the italian detective had in the first instance tried to come to terms with [him]139-quadling , demanding 50,000 francs as [his]139-quadling price for allowing [him]139-quadling to go at large ; that when [Quadling]139-quadling distinctly refused to be black - mailed , [Ripaldi]99-ripaldi struck at [him]139-quadling with a knife , but that the blow failed to take effect . Then [Quadling]139-quadling closed with [him]99-ripaldi and took the knife from [him]99-ripaldi . It was a fierce encounter , and might have ended either way , but the unexpected entrance of [the woman Petitpré]1223-the woman petitpré took off [Ripaldi]99-ripaldi 's attention , and then [he]99-ripaldi , [Quadling]139-quadling , maddened and reckless , stabbed [him]99-ripaldi to the heart . It was not until after the deed was done that [Quadling]139-quadling realized the full measure of [his]139-quadling crime and its inevitable consequences . Then , in a daring effort to extricate [himself]139-quadling , [he]139-quadling intimidated [the woman]1700-the woman [Petitpré]80-hortense petitpré , and forced [her]1700-the woman to escape through the sleeping - car window . It was [he]139-quadling who had rung the signal - bell to stop [the train]145-the train and give [her]1700-the woman a chance of leaving [it]145-the train . It was after the murder , too , that [he]139-quadling conceived the idea of personating [Ripaldi]99-ripaldi , and , having disfigured [him]99-ripaldi beyond recognition , as [he]139-quadling hoped , [he]139-quadling had changed clothes and compartments . On the strength of this confession [Quadling]139-quadling escaped the guillotine , but [he]139-quadling was transported to [New Caledonia]54-new caledonia for life . The money taken on [him]139-quadling was forwarded to [Rome]7-rome , and was usefully employed in reducing [his]139-quadling liabilities to [the depositors in the bank]1226-the depositors in the bank . The other word . Some time in June the following announcement appeared in all the [Paris]1-paris papers : " Yesterday , at [the British Embassy]1325-the british embassy , [General Sir Charles Collingham]56-sir charles , [K. C. B.]140-k. c. b. , was married to [Sabine]111-sabine , [Contessa di Castagneto]120-the contessa castagneto , [widow of [the Italian Count of that name]2335-the italian count of that name]2334-widow of the italian count of that name .
